title: Besides blasting Trump, Democratic presidential candidates offer few details on immigration plans so far
content:
CLOSE Former VP Joe Biden is leading the pack of 2020 Dems by a wide margin . What does the former VP think of the field of Democrats. ? Buzz60
Pete Buttigieg made a campaign stop in Miami last week , speaking in a city defined by immigration in a county where a majority of residents are foreign-born .
The South Bend , Indiana , mayor and Democratic presidential candidate briefly spoke about providing a pathway to citizenship for the nation 's 11 million undocumented immigrants and stressed the need to reshape the federal government 's treatment of migrants seeking refuge in the USA .
`` The last time I was in church , I was hearing Scripture about taking care of the least among us and defending the poor and welcoming the stranger , which is another word for immigrant , '' he said .
After a couple of minutes , Buttigieg pivoted away from the topic , shifting to gun control , climate change and the need to eliminate the Electoral College . In doing so , he joined other top Democratic candidates in largely avoiding the controversial topic of immigration in the early stages of the 2020 campaign .
Most Democratic candidates have decried the most extreme aspects of President Donald Trump 's immigration strategy , blasting his family separation policy , vowing to reverse his decision to end protections for DACA ( Deferred Action for Childhood Arrival ) recipients and lamenting the images of `` kids in cages . ''
But they have largely shied away from explaining how they would deal with the record-setting surge of Central American families seeking asylum , secure the southern border or overhaul a 50-year-old legal immigration system that 's in dire need of an update . That strategy runs the risk of allowing Trump to define the immigration debate with his accusations that Democrats support `` open borders '' and migratory lawlessness .
Of the 24 declared Democratic candidates , nine have some kind of immigration proposal posted on their campaign website .
Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts , whose `` I have a plan for that '' slogan has defined her campaign , does not have an immigration plan on her website . Sen. Michael Bennet of Colorado , who was part of the `` Gang of Eight '' group of senators that passed a comprehensive immigration plan in 2013 , dedicates just nine words to immigration on his website : `` Michael will work to fix our broken immigration system . ''
Joe Biden , who led President Barack Obama 's efforts to improve living conditions in the Central American countries where most migrants are coming from , barely mentions that work in the one-paragraph immigration section on his website . Sen. Kamala Harris of California , who has tackled immigration detention and other difficult immigration issues , makes no mention of immigration on her website .
Only three candidates have released full immigration proposals . Two of them – former Department of Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julián Castro and author Marianne Williamson – barely crack the top 10 in polls . The third is Beto O'Rourke , the Texan who is polling higher but released his plan only Wednesday .
The lack of clearly articulated immigration proposals from the front-runners worries many Democratic operatives , including Simon Rosenberg , who has worked the issue since his time on President Bill Clinton 's 1996 campaign through his role as a senior adviser to the 2018 Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee .
`` Trump has told the country that this is one of the most important issues facing the nation . If the president says that , to not have a coherent , strong and developed view on it is dangerous , '' said Rosenberg , president of NDN , a Washington-based liberal think tank . `` The greatest danger for Democrats on the immigration issue is to duck . ''
Others said there 's not much for Democrats to gain by diving into thorny questions of immigration enforcement , border security and guest worker visas .
Pushed by Trump 's constant Twitter outbursts and speeches about the dangers of immigration , the issue consistently ranks as the top , or among the top , issues for Republican voters . Not so for Democrats , who usually rate health care , gun control and climate change far higher on their list of concerns .
According to a poll in October conducted by the Pew Research Center , illegal immigration was deemed the biggest problem facing the nation by Republicans and the 18th biggest problem by Democrats .
`` Does that mean ( Democratic candidates are ) uninterested or it 's too controversial or it 's unimportant ? No . It means that other issues are priorities in a Democratic primary , '' said Frank Sharry , executive director of America 's Voice , a group that advocates for immigrants in the USA , who has advised several Democratic candidates on their emerging immigration proposals .
At least four candidates will participate in a presidential forum in Pasadena , California , on Friday hosted by immigration advocacy groups . In June , all the top candidates presumably will be asked about immigration during the first Democratic presidential debates in Miami that will be co-hosted by the Spanish-language network Telemundo .
That , according to Tom Jawetz of the liberal Center for American Progress , will be when candidates start digging deeper into immigration and forming what will become the party platform on the issue .
For now , he said , it 's important that Democrats continue telling voters how shameful Trump 's immigration track record has been . As the president forges ahead with his own interpretation of the immigration landscape , Jawetz said , Democrats will have to flesh out their own plans .
`` One thing we found through polling is that Trump does more damage to his support when he talks than we can when we open our mouths , '' he said . `` But I do n't think that 's sustainable . We 're going to have an increasingly loud conversation over the next 17 months on the issue . People ca n't afford to be silent about it . ''
